what is a merism?
A merism is a figure of speech that uses two opposite or contrasting terms to describe something as an entirety. It emphasizes the idea that the thing being described has both positive and negative aspects, or that it encompasses all possibilities within its definition. Merisms are often used in literature, poetry, and other forms of writing to convey complex ideas with simple language. Examples of merisms include "life and death," "good and evil," "love and hate," and "joy and sorrow."
